{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3561044,"name":"","username":"JaxsonSP","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/48db29/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-18T20:15:41.691Z","cooked":"

It is a little hard to describe the problem we are having so I have attached a video below. essentially the swerve drive is functioning correctly unless I release the controller stick (so ySpeed xSpeed and rot = 0) before it reaches its desired state/angle, in which case it spins around seemingly randomly indefinitely. When I provide a new xSpeed, ySpeed, or rot value it fixes itself and begins responding as expected. Here is the video:

At first I assumed it was a PID issue but seeing as giving a rot value (which also spins the wheels) does not have the same indefinite spinning problem I no longer think its that. Since I am pretty inexperienced in robotics coding and our teams only coder I just used the official robotpy/examples//SwerveBot code and tried to convert it to work with our canSparkMax + CTRE can encoder setup. I am assuming that is where the problem is, pretty much everything besides swervemodule.py and the network tables stuff is original and not mine so that should be fine. My PID values are p=0.2 i=0 d=0.01.
here is the git repo in case anyone wants to take a look, We really appreciate any help we can get: GitHub - Jaxson098/9019-2025: code for team 9019 2025 season

It does seem like a PID tuning issue, where it’s oscillating around the target rotation of the module. You should print the commanded effort, error, and target rotation to the dashboard to know for sure.

Also, does this issue occur on the ground? Did you tune your PID on the cart or on the ground?

PID was never really tuned, just using low standard values (at least from what I understand). To answer your question he error persists on the ground, the wheels power through the ground resistance to keep spinning when ySpeed = 0.

could be that the joystick is drifting, check in driverstation if the stick returns to 0, and if not you should apply a small deadband

Stick does have small drift (0.2 at the most) but I have applied a large deadband (0.4)

Printed out the values, it keeps switching between -90 and 90 as the desired angle. I assumed this with a problem with enabling Continuous Input but after double checking my code I couldn’t find a problem with it. here is a video: https://youtube.com/shorts/AmKec8oPXkg?feature=share
